newsitem.title: USA: U.S. spot resids still supported by hot weather.
newsitem.headline: U.S. spot resids still supported by hot weather.

text.p: U.S. spot fuel oil prices mostly held steady again Wednesday in moderate activity, with strong gas prices and a scorching East Coast heat wave still underpinning the complex, industry sources said.

"The summer cooling season has begun and burns are picking up. Things are looking better," said one cash trader, adding heat this week on the East Coast stirred utility interest, particularly with gas less competitive after recent gains.
In New York Harbor, physical one percent was unchanged at $16.00-25 a barrel, with 300,000 barrels for early July delivery sold at $16.25.
Traders said 100,000 barrels of prompt one percent sold at $16.80 (delivered price to Connecticut).
NYH July one percent paper firmed by about a quarter to $16.50 on stronger crude, traders said.
NYH 0.3 percent high pour again gained slightly to the high-$17 area, helped by improved generation load that should yield more utility demand.
High sulphurs in New York were stable, with 2.2 percent still talked at $14.50-75..
Traders reported a 1.5 percent cargo sale to a New York utility for delivery by July 7 but the price was unknown.
At the U.S. Gulf, one percent held steady at $15.75-16.00, while three percent notionally slipped a quarter to $13.25-50.
A Florida utility tendered for 350,000 barrels of 2.5 percent for delivery by August 1.
A trader said 200,000 barrels of three percent for July 10 delivery to Mississippi sold at $13.60.

New York city gate swing gas prices held relatively steady Wednesday in the low-$2.60s/mmBtu, or $16.57 a barrel equivalent. Gas at Henry Hub, the NYMEX delivery point, also was unchanged at about $2.31/mmBtu, or $14.55 a barrel.
